content: Yes, this extension to the utility function could capture the "catching up with the Joneses" effect. In this extension, gamma represents the strength of the social comparison effect, where the utility from consumption of the individual depends on how much their consumption deviates from the aggregate consumption of the reference group. As a result, individuals may feel pressure to consume at levels similar to their peers or reference group, leading to a "keeping up with the Joneses" effect. The term X\*log(n(i)\_t) represents the disutility of working, where a higher level of work (1-n(i)\_t) leads to lower utility.
